sub_topic: Probability of a certain type of traffic accident occurring on a road
message_1: A certain road section has a probability of 0.15 of an accident involving a truck, 0.20 of an accident involving a car, and 0.65 of no accident. If you randomly pick a car accident, what is the probability that it involves a truck?
message_2:
The question seems to be asking for the probability of an accident involving a truck, given that an accident has occurred and it involves a car. However, this situation is contradictory, as an accident cannot involve both a truck and a car at the same time in the given problem.

If you meant to ask for the probability of an accident involving a truck, given that an accident has occurred (regardless of whether it involves a car or a truck), then we can use the conditional probability formula:

P(A|B) = P(A ∩ B) / P(B)

In this case, A represents the event of an accident involving a truck, and B represents the event of an accident occurring (either involving a truck or a car).

P(A) = 0.15 (probability of an accident involving a truck)
P(B) = 0.15 + 0.20 = 0.35 (probability of an accident occurring)

Since the events are mutually exclusive (an accident cannot involve both a truck and a car at the same time), P(A ∩ B) = P(A) = 0.15.

Now we can calculate the conditional probability:

P(A|B) = P(A ∩ B) / P(B) = 0.15 / 0.35 ≈ 0.4286

So, if an accident has occurred, the probability that it involves a truck is approximately 0.4286 or 42.86%.
